title: Final momentum due to applied force

content.question: A student conducts an experiment in which an object travels across a horizontal surface while for <math alttext="2 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>s</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> a net force is applied to a <math alttext="2 kilogram " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2 kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> object that initially travels with a speed of <math alttext="0.5 meter per second " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.5 m/s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Data collected from the experiment are used to create the graph of the magnitude of the applied force exerted on the object as a function of time is shown. All frictional forces are considered to be negligible. Can the student use the graph and the known data to determine the momentum of the object after the force has been applied?

choices.label: Yes, because the average force exerted on the object can be used with the time interval of <math alttext="2 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2 s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to determine the change in momentum of the object by using <math alttext="delta vector p equals vector F delta t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover><mo>=</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow></mover><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Yes, because the area bound by the best-fit line and the horizontal axis from <math alttext="0 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0 s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="2 seconds " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>2 s</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be used to determine the change in momentum of the object.
No, because the data is too scattered to determine the average force that is exerted on the object.
No, because the student needs to know the direction that the force is applied to the object because the applied force will be in the same direction as the change in momentum of the object.

content.answer: No, because the student needs to know the direction that the force is applied to the object because the applied force will be in the same direction as the change in momentum of the object.
